Wheel parts of a caster wheel on a small filing drawer unit thing broke, attempting a repair... will update if it works, eventually.  
Similarish to Ikea Malm drawer unit.  
Dimension notes in the Wheel.scad file, variables can be changed to fit your needs.  
Uses pins.scad, but personally modified the modules to allow for $fn overrides (and different split gap on smaller, longer pins), since i want them smooth-ish spinning yet attached very well.  This cabinet doesn't move too often, so just having the wheel there to allow it to balance is the key for me.

Files:

  • Pin5.stl & Pin5.scad

    • Final version of the pin, needed some trimming still to work, but overall worked very well.
      Print as dense as possible... I did 50% since my printer fails on 100% too often
      Really, I'd suggest find a metal bolt that you could use if you need real durability.

  • Wheel.stl & Wheel.scad

    • Final version of the wheel, worked great. Printed with 50% cura fill, and supports that needed to be cleaned off (wanted the curved part to be as smooth as possible)

  • Wheel.failV1.scad

    • Original version, forgot to change the pin size from default... total fail

  • Pin.scad & Pin.stl

    • ORIGINAL VERSION, failure, not enough flex, too big.
  • V1Correction.scad
    • Fix for "Wheel.failV1.scad", fill the gap from the default radius (4mm) to the actual radius (5.75/2mm)

author: tomapowa

description.text:
I've got this RAM Tough Dock monitor mount installed in my truck that holds my Panasonic Toughbook.  I recently added a wired rear view camera on my 5th wheel and needed a place to mount the monitor for that.  
This adapter mounts where the "laptop monitor stabilizing arm" usually goes on the RAM Tough Dock.  My tough dock never came with the arm, and the monitor/lid has such a stiff lid that I wouldn't even need it.  
This mount connects directly to that point and allows a 1" RAM ball mount to be connected to the side of the dock.  From there, a short arm will be attached to the monitor.  
More pictures will follow as I complete and install it back into the truck.  I printed a white one initially, then once I confirmed that it was good, printed a final one in black.  Only ONE is needed to mount to the side of the RAM Tough Dock.

This is the concept.
This is not checked.
It is on lmuu8

Well, I started out wanting to do some nicer fillets on my OpenScad designs, and suddenly, I have a full blown Bezier surface/solids library! This thing is the Version 1.0 for this stuff. I think it's actually good enough to produce some nice looking objects. The technique used here is a linear extrusion of a bezier surface. The surface itself is described by 16 control points in a mesh. The machinery then takes care of rendering that to the thickness that you want. The workhorse module can be found in the Renderer.scad file: DisplaySurfaceMesh() This will generate a surface, according to your mesh, and extruded to the thickness that you specify (default 1mm). It is a solid, so it will play nicely with the other CSG functions in OpenScad. There are a few demo/test/samples provided in the .scad files, so it should be fairly easy to make up your own examples. I use colors in the examples because it makes for some pretty pictures. They don't affect the rendering process at all. If you don't like the color ramps, you can select your own. Although this version provides only one mechanism for doing solids from the Bezier surface mesh, it has all the fundamentals for you to do other forms as well. you don't even have to use the Bezier functions for bezier surfaces, you can use them for anything where you'd like something to vary in a parametric sort of way in your designs. The color ramps are another example of how the Bezier curves can be used. At any rate, there are other forms of curves, and more rendering methods to be pursued. RapCAD is doing some interesting work, and hopefully Bezier shows up as a core feature of these various text based tools. But, until that day... enjoy! UPDATE: Blog entry to go with it:
http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/05/26/linear-extrusion-of-bezier-surfaces/

1) Start with the maths.scad, bezier.scad, and Renderer.scad files in a directory where you're going to build your Bezier surface based stuff.
2) Come up with the control points for your mesh. You will need 16 of them.
3) Feed the mesh to the DisplaySurfaceMesh() routine in the Renderer.scad file
4) Stand back and watch the sparks fly (or the plastic melt as it were)
5) Rejoice!

comments.text:
Well I thought I had cracked it by using the latest Renderer library and the shell_extrude_bezier function.
But.. if you try to combine a surface generated by either the above function or the linear_extrude_bezier function you end up with
"Object isn't a valid 2-manifold!" when trying to export the stl.
//example code using OpenSCAD version 2014.03
include <renderer.scad>
gcp4 = [[0,30,0], [10,40,0], [20,40,0], [30,30,0]];
gcp3 = [[5,20,10], [10,20,20], [15,25,15], [20,20,5]];
gcp2 = [[5,10,10], [10,10,20], [15,5,15], [20,10,5]];
gcp1 = [[0,0,0], [10,-10,0], [20,-10,0], [30,0,0]];
union() {
shell_extrude_bezier([gcp1, gcp2, gcp3, gcp4], steps=16, thickness=3);
translate([13,13,-20]) cylinder(h=50,r=4);
}

title: Breast Cancer Ribbon, Rebuilt for less printing issues on the top right edge.

description.text:
This is a slight simplification of the original model, without hole, and without the strange behaviour of the upper right bending border, while printing.  I redesigned it from scratch. 
The main difference is that all the surfaces and curves are horizontal. There is not vertical bending of the curve. But the 3d effect remains. With the same elevated borders.  
I had to rebuild it from its 2d base shade to get this result, after hours trying to change the original model without success.

remixed_from.author: misan
remixed_from.title: Bronze sintered bushing adapter for LM8UU replacement

title: Customizable LM8UU graphite impregnated bronze bushing adapter

description.text: After a tip by Ruff, I decided to test graphite impregnated bronze bushings to replace LM8UU linear bearings, as a way to decrease the noise from my P3Steel and Prusa i3 printers when printing. I made a video comparing the noise of these graphite impregnated bronze bushings to that of a low cost LM8UU bearing: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AbSU_rI82-4 These printed adapters have customizable tolerances which can be adjusted to your specific printer to get a perfect fit of the bushings. The default values are the ones I arrived at after a few tries. Based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:849572 by Ruff, and also on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:166794 by Misan. OpenSCAD sources are included so the thing can be further remixed. Released under the GPLV3 license.

Here printed in PLA with 35% infill.  
Requires two bushing per adapter.  
These graphite impregnated bronze bushing are available from AliExpress for less than $0.35 each, in packs of 10.  
I put them in the fridge for about an hour before press-fitting them in the still warm adapter.

comments.text:
When going from bearings to bushings you have to be much more careful about alignment. Bushings will not give you any help and if they are misaligned even slightly you will get a lot of resistance.
Do not compare/test a single bushing vs a single bearing, test e.g. the entire x carriage w/3-4 bearings against the same with bushings.
One trick that can help is to print in ABS and then use acetone to soften the plastic a lot, then run a burn-in cycle with lots of movement while the ABS hardens.
comments.author: oysteinkrog

comments.text: I agree with you 100%, alignment is MUCH more critical with bushings than with linear bearings. The acetone idea is a good one I think, I may have to try it soon. Thanks.

author: slavikk

description.text:
50an6xy06r6n's version 7.1 didn't fit all too well on my Simple Metal. It scraped the first print layers off the bed and was about 1.4mm too long towards the Z-probe. As a result, the Ubis hot end was offset from the centre (towards the fans side.) It also hit the printer frame above the X-motor when homing Y and Z. I have modified his design slightly so that my hot end is centred within the shroud.
I decreased the profile by approximately 1mm in order to better clear the bed and not scrape it.
I increased the clearance where it is near the printer body on homing. v7.1.2 is similar (part printed in blue), but I increased the internal volume by adding height to the portion that surrounds the extruder (to try and reduce back pressure.) Print Results:
So far so good, a 3hr print came out extremely clean. And no clearance issues at all. NOTE: I'm not 100% sure if the SW 7.1 file corresponds to the 7.1 .stl file in terms of exact dimensions as something was most likely altered inadvertently.

PLA @ 208 degC
I printed it at 25mm/s with a 0.2mm resolution. (1h19)
Unsupported.
I used rafting as I was having issues with adhesion on the bed due to cold weather.

comments.text:
This looks like it would clear up some problems for me as well. Is there good airflow coming out of the bottom?
I've been getting a lot of problems with warping and curling of PLA. I have tried lower printing temps, slower printing speeds and everything, I just dont know why slight overhangs curl up so terribly.
I'm currently waiting for a replacement fan to arrive since I broke the original one, but I think I should have bought a stronger fan...
comments.author: ZideYT

description.text:
Note that I just uploaded "improved" versions of the spindle and latch. This set is not useful by itself, it is part of my modular device holder system. This is a generic device holder, which can be customized for any specific phone/tablet using the thingiverse customizer. There are 2 included STLs for iPhone5 and 6 with a basic bumper case, but I strongly encourage you to use the customizer and size it exactly for your device. With the right size you often don't even need extra bits to hold the device in. You should also download the spindle, and optionally the latch. To make it useful, see these related things (more coming):
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1194035
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902840
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:902862

Note:  you need the "device_spindle.stl" and optionally "device_holder_latch.stl" in addition to the customized holder to make practical use of this thing.   
This is a customizable phone or tablet holder. When combined with other pieces, you can make a nice tabletop stand, car holder, etc. which can be rotated 360 degrees in 90 degree steps. This and all related parts are designed to print well without support, and should work well with most materials.   
Measure the dimensions of your device (with case) carefully and enter into the customizer.   
There are 3 strategies for holding the device in-place. For my desktop stand, I just use gravity. In the car, I use the rotatable plastic clips, and for my microphone stand tablet mount, I use rubber grommets. The holder has a set of convenient small screw holes for any such attachments.

title: Iris Business Card
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is an iris mechanism built into a business card sized card. For simplicity and to help keep the thickness low it only has 3 leafs. This particular design does not scale well to more leafs unless it is made much larger. The initial design did have 4 leafs and is built in a way that would allow it to scale to a different number of leafs more easily. If anyone is interested I could upload that as well.

Cut the parts out of a sturdy paper (I use .014" thick card stock) and follow the video instructions here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bybPiB00voE
Instead of the peel and stick adhesive you can just use any decent paper glue. Elmer's glue works fine, just be careful not to let any into the moving parts of the card.

description.text: Undercarriage support wall for the Durafly™ HyperBipe 900mm EPO (http://www.hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__33470__Durafly_HyperBipe_900mm_EPO_PNF_.html). The Durafly HyperBipe is a great model, however when using the undercarriage with the pre-installed slot, the EPO foam behind it tends to compress after a few hard landings, causing the undercarriage to lose stability. This support wall helps to resist the foam compression. Features a chamfered edge to help insert the support wall into the EPO foam.

• Print the support wall with ABS or PLA using 85-90% infill to ensure rigidity as this object is only 2mm thick to minimise weight.

  • Use a hobby knife to cut out a 46mm long, 2mm thick gap directly behind the pre-installed undercarriage slot. Be aware that the undercarriage slot has a horizontal part buried about 14mm deep in the fuselage so don't cut into it.

  • Place some ABS/PLA plastic and EPO friendly glue (e.g Foam safe CA or Epoxy) into the gap you just made, and on both sides of the support wall.

  • Centre the support wall in the middle of the fuselage behind the pre-installed undercarriage slot then firmly push the support wall into the gap until the top is flush with the fuselage.

  • Wipe off any excess glue including any glue that may have dripped into the pre-installed undercarriage slot.

title: Surfboard Modem Cover
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The lighs on my new Motorola / Arris Surfboard SB6141 Cable Modem are REALLY BRIGHT! I designed this cover to slide on the front and have the same form factor as the body itself. I still wanted to see the lights (but much much dimmer), so I used white filament (ABS), 100% infill, and made it 2mm thick. In complete darkness, I can see still the activity light flashing, and the send/receive lights VERY FAINTLY. I've attached the (quickly thrown together) openSCAD file in case anyone wants to mess with it.  Print it thicker or in black if you don't want to see the lights at all at night.  
I'm assuming this would also work with the SB6121. The SB6183 appears to be slightly wider, so would need some tweaks.
EDIT: user Zen1 reports (see comments) scaling the width to 116% fits the SB6183

title: Iris Greeting Card
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an iris mechanism built into a greeting card sized card (5" x 7"). For simplicity and to help keep the thickness low it only has 3 leafs. This particular design does not scale well to more leafs unless it is made much larger. The initial design did have 4 leafs and is built in a way that would allow it to scale to a different number of leafs more easily. If anyone is interested I could upload that as well.
This card has slots in the back that allow you to stick a 2" x 3" photo in the back and reveal it when the iris is opened.
I have this setup for 8.5" x 11" sheets, but if you have a bigger sheet you can combine the two files.

Cut the parts out of a sturdy paper (I use .014" thick card stock) and follow the video instructions here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wl4Lhaqy89c Instead of the peel and stick adhesive you can just use any decent paper glue. Elmer's glue works fine, just be careful not to let any into the moving parts of the card.

Inspired by the starship enterprise, posted as thing No. 8100 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8100), I converted a google 3d galery model of a romulan warbird (http://sketchup.google.com/3dwarehouse/details?mid=c5b88c16e0091eed6208ceb8c2299bcc&prevstart=0) to a printable stl file. Because of several overhangs, I had to cut the ship into pieces to get a printable version.
Now the ship consists of 4 parts: The left side, the right side and the 2 panels.
The size is about 100 mm x 70 mm x 2.5 mm. The print was very good on my mendel with a layer thickness of 0.2 mm in glowing-in-the-dark PLA.
After cleaning (which is not very much work, if you set your retraction distance long enough) I glued it together. The panels should klick into the wings - otherwise they also can be glued. You can read more about this on: www.ifeelbeta.de Live long and prosper!
BonsaiBrain
Print it, glue it together and play star trek!

title: Geo Key Bow and Keychain (X180 / B69)

description.text:
The keys for my 1995 Geo Tracker were looking a bit behind of their time. This key fob thing is meant to encase the head of any X180 / B69 keys, the kind often used with 90s Chevrolet GEOs, and give them a new look.  
Also included is a generic Geo logo keychain thing. You can optionally print two of these and glue the halves together.  
For the key fob/key bow piece, just place your X180 / B69 key into the recess, and use any reasonably short screws to firmly hold the retention piece in place (I cut some old wood screws down to length). Optionally, you can use glue or epoxy.

This is my first thing upload. It is a round eye glasses nose piece design. I designed this with SolidWorks. The thing is very small, please take a look at the pictures showing comparison with a dime besides it. In fact, the thing is so small that it is hard to take pictures of it, especially that I printed it with clear PLA filament. Design notes:
  • Note that the nose piece holders on the eye glasses DO NOT have screws to hold the nose pieces. The holders are ditched in to clamp on to the nose pieces in place. My design included a small hole for the ditches to clamp on to, so the nose piece move up and down freely once fitted on to the ditches.
  • The nose piece is 0.3 inches in diameter, 0.2 inches total height, and the thickness to insert to the holder is 0.055 inches.

I printed this thing using clear PLA. Since the thing is so small, I did not even turn on the heated bed, and I printed directly on the blue tape. Maybe it was the PLA material, I used 175C on the nozzle. The filament did not want to stick to the bed at higher temperatures.

remixed_from.author: 3dAl
remixed_from.title: Dry Box for Large Spools with Roll Base

description.text: I wanted to keep my filament from absorbing moisture while it sat on my printer. I initially use the feeder found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:578157 in the lid of the tub but it made changing spools difficult because taking off the lid pulled more filament. This mounts on the side of the tub so you can remove the lid without changing the feed path. On the other end I made this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:856967 to hold the tube securely to the print head. It's threaded for 1/8" NPT push connectors. The mounting holes fit #8 nuts and screws.

I printed mine in ABS with 100% infill and 0.2mm layer height. You can probably reduce the infill significantly. Comment with your build settings if you use different values.
Besides the #8 nuts and screws I used these connectors:
http://amzn.com/B00A150R3O
and this teflon feed tube:
http://amzn.com/B00HY7QUYC

title: Bulkhead adapter from 2L bottle thread to 1/4" NPT

description.text: This adapter connects a 2L bottle with a 1/4" NPT adapter. The 0.53" hole is sized to be taped or a brass fitting can be screwed directly in. A 1"-8 UNC thread on the outside allows the adapter to be passed through a plate/bulkhead and secured with a nut, like the one from here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:869643/#files. v3 is usable as-printed. v4+ have a plug in the center that needs to be drilled out with a 0.5" drill. The plug is to improve bridging while printing. *v6 increases the thickness of the plug; I had some issues bridging with the 0.4mm bridge in v4

author: shiftycow

description.text:
Been messing around taking apart nerf guns see how they work also took apart a couple knockoffs.  Challenged myself to come up with my own design and this is the result after messing around on and off for about a year I finally printed a version that works this is the 4th generation.   
Coming soon 3D Printed Nerf Double Barrel Shotty...   
I left the gun mostly blank except for shameless promotion but I would really like to see everyone go at it and remix remake retweak to your hearts desire right now it shoots about twenty feet all nerf guns have to shoot 75 feet so help me remix this thing and get 75 feet.  Also trick it out!!!!

Okay so you will have to scale these models by x1.15 ... this will basically allow the dart to slide into the nozzle. I printed out a bunch of different sizes and this seemed to work the best,,, I would also try x1.16 it may be too loose or just right... depends on your printer...You will need 4 different springs for this gun and 3 o-rings you can find the springs at a hardware store they do not sell the right ones at blowes or homecheapo .... You will need to use ABS to Abs glue.. not transition glue but straight up ABS glue, also grab some plumbers grease or heat grease.. you will need to coat the o-rings so they glide in the pipe.. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tPKA3qQfgOA&feature=youtu.be

  • Qty 1, Adafruit Pro Trinket LiIon/LiPoly Backpack ($4.95 ea)
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/2124
  • Qty 1, Lithium Ion Polymer Battery - 3.7v 2500mAh ($14.95 ea)
    http://www.adafruit.com/products/328
  • Glue, Solder, Soldering Iron and optionally paints and brush.
    • Optional Hardware for Wall-Mount / Desk-Mount stands:
  • Qty 1 (pack of 25), M2x6 Metric Screw ($10.95ea)
    http://www.mcmaster.com/#91239a704/=ykc2qm
  • Qty 1, 1.3mm Hex Allen Key ($0.20)
    http://www.mcmaster.com/#6958a23/=ykc3ko
    ** Note: You can just glue the two stand pieces together if you
    don't wish to use/purchase the screw hardware.
    • PRINT ORIENTATION STRATEGY: Mask halves (left and right) printed in the vertical orientation benefits
  • Good for users that may have a smaller print bed
  • Good for users with low warp materials
  • Good to push z height layer lines towards the outside of mask,
    preserving better quality towards the center of the mask and
    reducing post print clean up.
    http://goo.gl/QPnXra
    http://goo.gl/rEOyPA
    • Single mask printed in the horizontal orientation benefits
  • Good for users with a larger print bed
  • Good for users who may have warping issues, as gluing the
    two halves together may become difficult if warping is to high.
    http://goo.gl/bVKjA7
    • SUPPORT GENERATION STRATEGY: Overall, the mask "almost" prints well without the need for
    supports. However, there are still a few problem areas that do
    need support, regardless if you are printing the single horizontal
    piece or the two separate left and right pieces vertically. In either
    case, I would recommend generating support, with a low threshold
    of 15 degrees (in relation to the print bed). This will prevent a lot
    of unnecessary support from being generated, and will ensure the
    main trouble areas are supported. Refer to the photo for example.
    Recommended Slic3r 1.2.9 config files are available for ABS/PLA
    for users that have a 0.4mm nozzle. Just import the config file
    into Slic3r, and then re-select your own personal printer from the
    "printers" drop down box. The configuration assumes you have
    a heated bed (if you don't, just disable that on the filament screen). ASSEMBLY: There are four small guide pins to temporarily hold the
    mask together (3mmLED-Small-Pin-v3.stl).
    These pins should just give you a snug fit, but still allow the mask
    halves to be easily separated. Depending on the tolerance of
    your printer; the pins may be too tight to easily insert into the
    holes. Don't force the pins, as you won't be able to easily separate
    and re-attach the two halves while applying glue. Scale the four
    pins down just a bit (95%?), re-print, and retry. It will only take
    a few minutes to reprint the 4 small pins. Now that you have good alignment, separate the two halves
    leaving the guide pins in place in one of the mask halves. Now
    grab your favorite glue and apply an appropriate amount along
    the seam. Now firmly press the two mask halves together and
    clamp until dry. If you want glowing horns, you will need to print the horns using
    a clear or translucent material. Cut a piece of Aluminum foil to
    6mm x 12mm. Use a small piece of scotch tape to secure the foil
    to the outer surface of the 6mm long light pipe (bottom/center of
    the horn). The shiny side should be facing inward. Next, insert a "large-guide-pin" into the base of the horn. Now
    press the horn and its guide pin into one of the masks horn
    sockets. The 54mm horn goes in the bottom socket, followed by
    55.8mm horn, and so on until you get to the 62.4mm horn on the
    top of the mask. (Glue the horns in place only if they are loose).
    The large guide pins have an outside diameter of 12.6mm and the
    inside diameter of the horn socket is 12mm. So you should have
    a tight fit (use pliers if needed to compress the guide clip as you
    insert it into the horn). If the fit is to tight, sand the guide clip down. Now grab your 3mm LEDs, insert them into the LED holes from the
    rear side of the mask, and secure with a drop or two of Super-Glue.
    Refer to the color rendering for color placement of the lower four
    horns. The top two horns should be amber. The 'mouth' LEDs
    are red, the 'nose' LEDs are orange, and the 'eyebrow' LEDs are
    Purple/UV. You can of course substitute any color you wish.
    The 'horn' LEDs will all be much brighter clear LEDs to help
    illuminate the horns, while the 'face' LEDs are generally less bright
    tinted LEDs to make them not so overpowering since they will be
    directly facing the viewer (the Purple/UV LEDs are the exception,
    as they are clear). Electronic wiring instructions to follow soon after print is done. :-)
    In essence, you will connect the battery to the charger, connect the
    charger to the Trinket Pro, connect all of the negative leads of the
    LEDs together, and then connect to the ground pin of the Trinket
    Pro. Each 'pair' of LED's (corresponding left and right side)
    should be connected to a unique output pin on the Trinket Pro
    There are 14 LED pairs;
  • 5 Horn pairs
  • 1 Eye pair
  • 1 Nose pair
  • 4 Mouth pairs
  • 3 Eyebrow pairs
    • I believe the Trinket can power the LEDs directly without current
    limiting resistors due to internal current limiting on the pin, but you
    should verify this first. You should be able to find plenty of code
    examples on Google to get the LEDs up and running. Otherwise,
    hang tight and I'll get a proper write-up posted soon. :-) DESK STAND: Print the two "Desk Stand" parts, and then glue them together, or
    use the recommended 2mmx6mm metric screws from McMaster.
    The mask can be quickly removed from the desk stand
    and replaced, as the mask just rests on three prongs.
    There are corresponding sockets on the rear side of the mask.

Again, I have not yet fully assembled this thing, so no guarantees
that anything will work. The mask could potentially vanish into
thin air during assembly. :-)

description.text:
Little Boo Peep's sheep after some crazy guy came by and punched the wool off of her. 
In my continuing line of Parametric Minecraft models, I bring you the skinned sheep. This cute cuddly little guy is the first of what I believe will be the standardize size for all future models. I have found in my goal of making all the models printable on a Makerbot that 5x is the only size that will fit pretty much across the board.
As always all models are parametric using a 1 pixel to X mm design plan. Now with better coded and commented code.
Minecraft is not mine, it is property of the wonderful Notch. I just design these interpretations of the mobs. If you like minecraft or want to try it please support Mojang and Notch, by buying the game they deserve it.

• Print one each of the Head, Body and Legs files.
  • Color in the model pieces using either markers or paint
  • Using spare 3mm filament attach and glue legs to body
  • Using your preferred gluing method attach the head to the body
  • Enjoy your cute sheep...no you can't shave him and keep his plastic wool, someone beat you to it.

description.text:
Para esta receta necesitarás lo siguiente:
  • Este soporte de casquillo
  • 6 Matrices de tres estrellas : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:838538/#files
  • Un gancho: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:611805
  • Una cadena: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:144912
  • Un casquillo para la bombilla (verificar que encaja en el soporte de bombilla.
  • Dos cables
  • Una regleta electrica

Cocinar a fuego fuerte en ABS o a medio en PLA, para conseguir una textura bicolor cambiar el filamento sin detener la impresión.  
Cortar 1/3 de la cadena, con un cutter cortar en C a favor de capa el ultimo eslabón y unirlo en el centro de los 2/3 restantes de cadena para conseguir una Y en la que todos los lados sean iguales. Para cerrar el eslabón usaremos una gota de acetona.  
RECUERDA: La acetona es toxica, y sus vapores pueden llevarte al valhalla, úsala en entornos ventilados. además en exceso puede modificar el color del ABS. Si estás usando PLA emplea cianoacrilato (loctite o similar).  
Pegaremos con acetona las 6 matrices de estrella en forma de hexágono, podemos ayudarnos con dos piezas 'soporte de bombilla' y unas gomas elásticas.  
Fijamos con acetona el 'soporte de bombilla' dentro del hexágono a uno o dos dedos de altura.  
Cortamos en C los tres eslabones finales de la cadena y los encajamos en tres de las matrices de estrella que no se toquen entre si, fijamos el eslabón con acetona.  
Nos ayudamos del gancho para colgar la lampara del eslabón central de la cadena, sujetamos el cable eléctrico a uno de los extremos de la cadena y encajamos a presión el portalámparas en el agujero central del 'soporte de bombilla', hacemos las conexiones eléctricas y verificamos que la lampara funciona correctamente.

to replace the stock killerbee board cam mount which doesn't allow much room to tilt your fpv camera upwards  
the holes are spaced for a 25mm mini board cam like the runcam PZ0420M but the file could be modified easily or just drill some new holes in for your bigger camera

Pan-Tilt for Fatshark camera 600TVL
the solutions offered are original to me too expensive and the solutions presented here do not really to my liking. That's why I worked out my own solution I present here.
Requires additionally, 2x Servo HK 15178 from Hobby King and several small screws (1.5 - 2 mm)
The solution provides a central receptacle for the Pan servo, and builds on that.
In the recording of the Pan-Servos a directional pad is embedded, which is screwed to the servo. In the coverage of the Pan servos is a cable guide for the camera feed. This line is installed in the recess and serves as strain relief. These two parts are screwed together with small screws.
The camera is placed in the camera shooting and the tilt servo is fitted. The camera recording is then screwed with a corresponding washer on the servo. The opposite side, meaning the bottom of the servos is carefully drilled with an appropriate drill - not pierce, the servo could be damaged.
Through the opening of the camera receiving a grub screw is then screwed in, which serves as a counter bearing.
The tilt servo is now bolted to the servo support of the Pan-servos.
Note:
the camera mount not print vertically, the edges of the camera recording break from usual, they sin as not flexible. Pan-Tilt für Fatshark Kamera 600TVL
die original angebotenen Lösungen sind mir zu kostspielig und die hier vorgestellten Lösungen haben mir nicht wirklich zugesagt. Deshalb habe ich mir eine eigene Lösung erarbeitet, die ich hier vorstelle.
Benötigt werden zusätzlich, 2x Servo HK 15178 von Hobbyking und diverse kleine Schrauben (1,5 - 2mm)
Die Lösung sieht eine zentrale Aufnahme für den Pan-servo vor und baut auf diesem auf.
In der Aufnahme des Pan-Servos ist ein Steuerkreuz eingelassen, das am Servo verschraubt wird. In der Abdeckung des Pan-Servos befindet sich eine Kabelführung für die Kamera-Zuleitung. Diese Leitung wird in die Aussparung verlegt und dient zusätzlich als Zugentlastung. Verschraubt werden diese beiden Teile mit kleinen Schrauben.
Die Kamera wird in der Kameraaufnahme platziert und der Tilt-Servo wird eingepasst. Die Kameraaufnahme wird dann mit einer entsprechenden Unterlegscheibe am Servo verschraubt. Die gegenüberliegende Seite, gemeint ist der Boden des Servos, wird vorsichtig mit einem entsprechendem Bohrer angebohrt, - nicht durchbohren, der Servo könnte beschädigt werden.
Durch die Öffnung der Kameraaufnahme wird dann eine Madenschraube eingeschraubt, die als Gegenlager dient.
Der Tilt-Servo wird nun am Servoträger des Pan-Servos verschraubt.
Anmerkung:
den Kameraträger nicht senkrecht drucken, die Flanken der Kameraaufnahme brechen sonst ab, sie sin so nicht flexibel. (Übersetzung durch Google-translate)

Camera Holder Print lie, as seen in the photo the camera cable is laid in the bottom of the servo-holder-top and is thereby additionally relieved of strain Video unter:
https://youtu.be/lrMxWGuSnuU (Übersetzung durch Google-translate)

title: G18c holster v3s cm030 (left handed included)

description.text:
El siguiente objeto se trata de una funda de pistola para modelos de tipo Glock 18 de airsoft. La he probado en la G18c Cm030 de Cyma y funciona perfectamente. Tambien en la Glock 18c de tokio marui y en la G23 de Kworks. En estos tres modelos la pistola entra en la funda encaja y se sujeta perfectamente. Disponeis de un video en youtube en la siguiente direccion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2c5w8ovsSb4 La funda se compone de 3 piezas:
g18_cm030_holster_v3s que es la funda en si.
locking_lever_for_g18c_holster_v3s palanca de retención de la pistola.
molepack version3 enganche de la funda al sistema mole. Sistema de retecion de la pistola.
Se compone de una palanca que tiene un tope. Al presionar esta libera la pistola y permite su extraccion. La palanca utiliza una pieza de espuma que la hace volver a modo de muelle a su posicion original. Funda para Zurdos: Los archivos left_handedlocking_lever_for_g18c_holster_v3s.stl y left_handed_g18_cm030_holster_v3s.stl son la misma funda pero adaptada para zurdos. Se necesitan las siguientes piezas no impresas.
1 x Tornillo allen 35mm de M3
1 x Tuerca M3
3 x Tornillos de sujecion de M5
3 x Tuercas de M5
1 x Pieza rectangular de material tipo espuma para el mecanismo de retención de 25 mm x 10 mm x 10 mm. La he impreso en material ABS. Se ha probado durante 6 meses todas las piezas han aguantado perfectamente el uso. Si os gusta el airsoft. No olvidéis ver mi canal de Youtube donde cuelgo reviews y reparaciones sobre pistolas de airsoft. Este lo encontrareis en la siguiente direccion: https://www.youtube.com/user/fransolomon

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

iprusa 3D steel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

60%

1) Imprimir las piezas. Repasar los agujeros con una pequeña lima para que entren bien los tornillos y las tuercas.
2) Situar el actuador "locking_lever_for_g18c_holster_v3s" en su zona y deslizar por el lateral de la funda un tornillo de M3 de 35 mm.
3) Insertar en el agujero situado en el lateral derecho del actuador un tornillo de M3.
4) Enrroscar el tornillo de 35 mm
5) Introducir por los agujeros de alojamiento de la funda "g18_cm030_holster_v3s"
3 tuercas M5.
6) Situar la funda sobre el enganche mole "molepack version3" en la posición que nosotros queramos y atornillar los 3 tornillos de M5 para fijarla al enganche.

comments.text:
Bueno, la he vuelto a imprimir redimensionandola para que fuese un 6% más grande en todas sus medidas, es decir, la he impreso al 106% pues midiendo el fichero con el solidworks vi que mi pistola al tener texturizado en algunas zonas era ligeramente más ancha, ahora entra bien y engancha, sin embargo queda algo suelta en la zona del gatillo, y por tanto hay juego hacia adelante y atras.
Si pudieses pasar el fichero fuente del boton al menos me harias un gran favor, ya que deberia echar el tope que engancha la pistola un poco más atras para reducir la holgura, si no ya veré de replicar ese modelo de boton para asi ajustar más la pistolera, ya que no me gusta ir como un sonajero andante por los campos jejeje.
comments.author: Shelmak

comments.text: Buenas normalmente no estoy atento a los comentarios de thingiverse.com suelo estar mas atento en mi canal de youtube. La pieza esta hecha en thinkercad y esta hecha para la pistola G18c de cyma. Seguramente la APS Dragon fly al tener punto de mira mas acentuado y otras partes mas sobre dimensionadas no encaje, lo digo por que un 106 % de mas en las medidas son como 1.62 mm mas de ancho en el hueco de entrada de la pistola. Pero seguramente estas medias ya las has realizado. A mi me preocupan algunas cosas que puedes afectarte en cuanto al sobredimensionado, los agujeros y las entradas para las tuercas pueden verse modificados y el resto de las piezas que hay para esta funda no te valdrian me refiero a los remixes que han hecho que te puedan interesar. Quizas lo suyo seria que te pasara un enlace al thinkercad para que pudieras modificar la pieza creo que con un correo valdra. Pues no trabajo con solidworks (actualmente estoy aprendiendo pero lleva su tiempo). Un saludo y gracias por tus comentario.

Is an holder for same juweleries
Trinitrotoluene, best known as a useful explosive material with convenient handling properties.
I made it using Avogadro+Blender.
I made a holder to place my Dremel 4000 in the vises that are sold by Lidl. Now I can use my Dremel 'handsfree', and rotate it in any desired position.

I printed this holder on an Ultimaker 3D-printer. Layer height 0.2, shell thickness 1.6, infill 40% and support everywhere. The little square on the bottom had to be filed down a little to make a snug fit. I just screwed in a m4 bolt for the hinge and used m5 bolt, washer and wingnut to close the holder.

title: Duplicator I3 Controlbox Cover for LCD v2.0

description.text:
The Second attempt at modding a Front angled cover for the duplicator I3's control box. This time, I added :
  • 40mm fan on the bottom side (would work best if back cover uses a fan extracting air too) Recommended screws would be 4 x M3x15.
  • Front button for emergency stopping and better gap between the original wheel and the print.(no springs or anything required)
    • The one in the pictures follows this config : PLA @195°C, 0.3 layers with 30% infill and 50mm/s speed (+ activate support) and it was done using my fresh Duplicator i3 in about 7.5 hours. https://youtu.be/sWB5ZUDnT1Y Don't forget to activate Support unless the LCD window is never gonna print correclty !!

Alloy wheel cleaner would probably have a slight impact on your further life expectancy, while drinking coffee out of it beside a Oxyuranus microlepidotus might result in an instant death.
Wikipedia says:

if even possible, would be extremely difficult and very expensive. A
safe situation is one where risks of injury or property damage are low
and manageable."
That's, in fact, not the case here.
We will all die anyway...

title: Mathematical maths shape fractal geode star dodecahedron

description.text: It's a manga star symbol, a higher symmetry thing. moreton bradley book, stl by george heart, adapted for myself for printing with abs, the underside of the stars is difficult to render straight, so i divided it in two halves to stick together. so that the nicest part of the stars is always on top on both sides... also included original full star STL and the base supports i made for it in sketchup and stl format. To join hemispheres i put a roll of sandpaper on a flat surface and sanded the tips almost imperceptibly, and then i filled a jar lid with thin ABS glue, and dipped the tips of all the stars in the glue, it took about 20 seconds, and then there were small drops holding to all the star tips and i affixed them to the other star tips. best to do hemispheres with ABS because the 20 degrees underside slopes and warping makes the under of the stars totally rough, so sticking the top on both sides makes a nice model with some kind of funky squirled insides surfaces. Be careful of the first layer on this because i tried at 0.1mm 7cm diameter and it didnt stick on at all due to slicer making a mistake, the 11cm model went perfectly, here is a video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gjyei0JHdq0&feature=youtu.be tags platonic symmetry maths snowflakes

A base for your minions of chaos! A round base with 8 facets. Each facet having a curvy arrow to represent the mark of chaos. Height, width, facet angle, arrow parameters, god, and slot parameters are all customizable. Known issues:
1) While the sides are technically customizable, there are errors with values other than 8.
2) No, changing your god does not change the color of the stl, it is just fluff.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Medium or high

Infill:

doesn't matter

If you want to change the arrow shapes that are on the sides, I suggest you play around with the code at: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:869074. But if you insist, here is the documentation for the arrows: The code below produces an arrow with curvy edges. It does this by intersecting and taking the difference of 4 pairs of circles. 2 circles form the tip of the arrow (set1), and 2 form the back of the tip of the arrow(set2). The sides of the shaft are formed by set3, and the tail of the arrow is formed by set 4. The circles are specified by a modified polar coordinate system called "easy_form" which is ={distance from origin to circle edge, radius of circle, angle between +x-axis and circle center in degrees}. This coordinate system is SLIGHTLY easier to get a grasp of entering values. Changing the first value will push a curve farther from the origin (the center of the arrow). Lowering the 2nd number will make a line more curvy (by lowering the radius of the circle it creates). Raising the 2nd number will make a line more flat (by increasing the radius of the circle it creates). Changing the 3rd number is how you get position control. The 3rd number is the angle that the angle that the line connecting the origin and the center of the circle will make with the x-axis.Both the first and the third parameters can be negative. Negative radii will fail silently. It is highly recommended that this program be used in OpenSCAD and not customizer. There is no input checking, and a lot of edge cases where circles will not intersect. If instead of an arrow looking thing, customizer or OpenSCAD show you two circles floating in space, it means that the circles are not intersecting, and the program is failing silently. If you wish to make a 2D file, use 0 for the height (I don't think this works in customizer). Offline, the program will also suggest a filename based on your parameters. The last 4 functions in this program are used to calculate the points where the circles intersect, which is used to calculate the length and width of the arrow. This information is available through the echo function, and not visible in customizer. So if you want to know the dimensions of your arrow, use OpenSCAD.

I have a few things waiting to be mounted on walls and this is how I wanted to do it for fast hanging, removal, and changing displays. For my specific use, I wanted to nail the base to the wall with finishing nails, and super glue (or double stick tape) the interlocking slider onto 3D printed parts. I have one case I'll go in brick with screws, so will pre-drill the holes enough to prevent splitting the plastic. You can have a wall to display 3D "art" and easily swap objects using the universal catch. The default size is pretty heavy duty, but it should easily scale down for lighter loads. The whole premise for this hanger is fast, easy, no tools, no fuss swapping of seasonal objects using an interlocking catch system. UPDATE: 6-28-15, I had an STL of the two-piece set, which never got uploaded, so I added it to the project.
Also featuring the small flag holder using the wall mount bracket.

title: Prusa i3 Box Frame Spool Holder

description.text: This is a spool holder designed to work with a 1 1/8" wood dowel which I happened to have on hand, but would work with anything that is around 1" in diameter. PVC pipe comes to mind as a another option. It mounts on top of the standard sized box frame. You would need to print two of the spool stand. The length of the rod can be adjusted to accommodate as many spools as you can fit on the top. The end caps are designed to fit the 1 1/18" dowel, but could be easily resized to fit different sizes. It is similar to this spool holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:390393 but a bit taller to accommodate larger spools and designed for the dowel instead of a printable bar.

author: tnever

title: Mount for Fluxient U2 Mini bike light (and similar lights)

description.text:
A mount designed for my Fluxient U2 mini bike light.  
Designed to replace the mount that came with the light, since this broke on me.   
This could be used to mount any flash-light to a bike; in order to do this, two O-rings would be required.

Printed in ABS for improved weather resistance (compared to PLA).  
Lots of support material was required. This was easy to remove.  
I painted this with two coats of yacht varnish to waterproof it.   
I also glued a layer of neoprene as padding between the mount and the light.  
Both of these additions are basically optional, and the mount would have worked without them.

author: hungryjoe

title: Speaker amplifier for Samsung Note 4 with case

description.text:
After having a phone with front facing speakers, I really found it annoying that to get decent sound from my Samsung Galaxy Note 4, I had to cup my hand around to the back. There's a few 'docks' with a similar concept for iPhones and such, so I mocked up a quick model for the Note 4.  
Please keep in mind that I made this for a Note 4 which had a Verus Iron Shield case on it. It's not a tight fit but it's at a stage that's good enough for me without having to remove the case.   
Can't say what other cases it'll work for though, sorry. Otterbox cases might be a bit too chunky but if you can't find another similar case amplifier thing that works with the case on, well, I'm not going to stop you trying! Slimmer cases might not fit so well, as a naked Note 4 fits very poorly into this.   
Anyway, I hope you like it and it works for you.   
For reference, mine was printed on the M3D Micro, which has a super small print area. Used Flashforge PLA. Print settings were low infil, medium detail, rafting enabled, support enabled, and model-on-model support enabled. Took around 10 hours to complete I think.

title: Phantom 1 Gimbal Rebuild for SJ4000 Action Camera

description.text:
There are times that I wish I could just buy something and use it as is.  Then I remember half the fun is tearing it apart and making it better.  This little project is a good example of that.  I purchased a cheap camera gimbal for my Phantom.  Looked OK, worked very well, but was super heavy and drove my flight time down to 3-4 minutes.  Being the tinkerer I am, I tore it apart.  I found that I could buy this gimbal cheaper than I could buy the controller and motors separately so it made me feel better about throwing away the heavy CNC metal parts.  I then designed lighter 3D printable components to replace them and this is the end result.  So far I am very happy with it.  After tuning it is rock solid, much more responsive than the original, and my flight time is back up to about 7 minutes when fully loaded with the FPV transmitter.  Some of this is due to the weight reduction but this rebuilt version is much more balanced than the original and allows me to turn the power way down on the gimbal controller which helps too.  Please note that this is specifically for the SJ4000 camera since I don't trust my piloting skills enough yet to send up a $300 GoPro.  
Note: I realize that the lens is off center in this arrangement.  This was a trade off for me.  I leverage the video out capability of the SJ4000 for my FPV video source.  With the USB port that carries the AV signal on the right side, I had to orient the camera as designed to allow the AV cable to be plugged in.

description.text: New improved Gardena nozzle for water rocket. The nozzle has a thread that fits into an ordinary plastic bottle. The improvement is that the nozzle is longer than the Gardena nozzle, which made i possible to design the inside of the nozzle so it's shape is reflecting to a real rocket nozzle. This means that the area of the waterbeam is much larger and resulting in at lager thrust. The thing is still under devolopment so please dont print before the final design is ready.

description.text:

It's a bracket with a 22 degree angle that is placed on a hook with suction cup from IKEA. The hook with suction cup can be found at http://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/80240440/ .

remixed_from.author: syvwlch
remixed_from.title: Trapezoid Screw Thread Module: Now with a Shaft!

description.text:
Obviously, the intent is not to print threaded rod. :-)
Rather, this should allow you to subtract threaded rod from an object to make it a lead nut.
To create two meshing threaded rods like in the demo images, they need to have different handedness (RH) but the same pitch, pitch radius and threadHeightToPitch. Their profileRatios must be complementary (sum up to 1) and they must be separated by a distance of twice their pitch radius.
Have fun with it and don't be shy about reporting bugs or requesting changes or extensions.

description.text:
This fits in with my gothic 10ft corridor series. Rather than have a basic floor (only), or four pillars to help conceal the joining of several 10ft corridor pieces, I made a decorative piece to spice up the table.  
I made the floor/pillars, but can't take credit for the design of the statues (though they are modded from the originals).
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6i4ImGio3VI
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dn6myNDToSY
A model of Zingy, the EDF Mascot.

Print the eyes at a small layer height to ensure the surface isn't too stepped. In the model photo shown I used 0.1mm layer height for the eyes, and 0.3mm for the body.  
The scale of the model may be a little skewed, so you may need to print at 1000% scale, and possibly also double the scale. The print in the photo is around 80mm high.  
Print the eyes at 98% scale compared to the body otherwise they can be a bit of a hard fit.

This goes in a drain and catches stuff too big to go through the holes. This is a corrective remix of HarlanDMii's Drain Cover that was having trouble rendering online and in OpenSCAD. UPDATE 2015-06-16:
-- STL Version 1.9-4 has the fluted post (handle) and should be printed with high fill or a thick shell since the skinny part is prone to breaking if hollow. UPDATE 2015-06-15:
-- I've added a non-customizer file in a zip file.
-- Added a 0.2mm "helper disk" to help printing adhesion. I have a few more things to release in the next version, if time allows... I don't think that they scaling feature works correctly since the the 38mm one I just tested seems to be 40mm in Makerware. Note: I've included a "Hi Res" STL version of the 40mm file. It is probably easiest to just use that one and scale it in your slicer rather than try to customize the correct scale.
Until the customizer version has more features, I would recommend that you simple download the "HiRes" STL file and scale it in your slicer for the correct diameter.

I needed a cover for my light switch because I didn't want people turning off my Hue smart lights from the power switch. I also however wanted to retain side access just in case. So I remixed this design, the only changes is the hole in one side for the aforementioned side access. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lxrtju9zf0p

I built this in order to mount some cheap LED Light bars I got from Ebay.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/7x-Hot-LED-Tube-Light-Bar-White-Light-7W-12V-36LED-Garden-580LM-Lamps-Pure-/290854780330 I use these likes for aquariums and indoor gardening. I needed a mounting system that allows for mounting to vertical or horizontal surfaces and allows for the projection angle to be adjustable. The files contain a single 2-part mount. Print 2 for each bar light you need to mount. This version adjusts in 36-degree increments instead of the limited 90-degree increments

comments.text: updated SCAD/STL to use .5mm tolerance instead of 1mm. At 1mm it was possible to rotate the end caps in the mounting bracket.  1mm was usable, but not quite as tight as I wanted. Also decreased the retention lip from 3mm to 2mm to save a little on plastic usage.

remixed_from.author: ffleurey
remixed_from.title: Direct-drive hinged extruder for E3D/J-Head hot-end (Prusa i3)

description.text:
I've used the original mk8 direct drive hinged extruder for quite a while now with my E3D V5 with dual fan for reliable PLA cooling and it just works for me, amazing design. However planning to update to E3D V6 I needed to modify the design a bit and for more reliable flexible printing etc I thought to allow the PTFE tubing run through the whole extruder frame so that you can insert a long tube, cut a hole to the spot where the motor gear and bearing are located, then allow the tube to continue all the way to the hotend. So tl:dr; V6 compatible, mounting points for two fans, 4mm hole through the whole frame for PTFE tubing. I uploaded two files from this, one with dual fan mounting holes as seen in pictures and one with the original left side fan mount only. NOTE: I don't have the V6 hotend yet, so I can't test the actual fit for now. UPDATE: 10th Nov. 2015
  • Added "Extruder_dual_loose.stl" with 0.2mm bigger holes all around the hotend/PTFE mounting. This should solve the tolerance issues on some printers and make assembly easier. The original design is still valid if you want a "tight fit" extruder and have your printer calibrated properly.

Printed mine from PLA without support.  
Set infill & perimeters depending on your printer and filament.  
You might need the drill the 4mm hole for the teflon tubing afterwards depending on the tolerances of your printer.

comments.text: Did you cut the PTFE on both sides of just the side where it faces the drive gear?
comments.author: markmcconachie

comments.text: It has to be cut from both sides since on the other side there's the drive gear, and on the other the bearing. So the tip of the PTFE tubing viewed from the front ends up looking like a triangle sortof. I just fixed the hotend to the extruder, inserted the tube as far as it went, then used razor blade to cut the tip so that both the gear and the bearing will get a good contact with the filament.

description.text:
This is an extended version of the FPV250 landing gear which is useful for people with the FPV250LH "Low Hung" variant where the fuselage hangs below on vibration isolation. It gives more clearance.  
This is my first hack using SketchUp (that file is included). Basically I kept the same mount and stretched the leg part upwards. You could take the model in SketchUp or another tool and do the same to your own pre-defined height, but I think it really needs to be re-designed with different/morre support struts across when it gets too long.  
Another change which is necessary is to widen the profile at least at the bottom, because after printing I get the feeling it could break easily with horizontal motion, if you land at an angle. This is just a quick first attempt for anyone who needs a longer landing gear quickly.  
I think a better solution would be to remove the legs altogether and have a helicopter skid, that way the battery could also be mounted underneath allowing more clearance for 6 inch props on the FPV250.

title: Belt Clip for a MedTronic MiniMed Paradigm Insulin Pump.

description.text: Replacement Belt Clip for a MedTronic MiniMed Paradigm Insulin Pump.

I designed this using Google Sketch up for my Wife after her belt clip snapped... again.  Now she has a belt clip and doesn't have to walk around without one for a week while she waits for the replacement to show up in the mail.  I made it a bit thicker because ABS is not as strong as the original plastic,  but it flexes a bit so I think it may actually hold up better.   This will flex slightly where the original just snaps. Time will tell.  
I rounded all the corners on the design before I printed it, But I am uploading the non-rounded corners version, because I don't know how to remove the rounded corners in sketch up and it makes it hard to edit.  Or if there is a way, I don't know how.   
I printed this on my Afinia Printer with full fill and it turned out great. This is my first design in sketch up so I'm happy with the way it turned out,  and of course that it actually fit.  
Unbelievable.  :)

author: emmiambra

title: Holistic Puzzle, can you solve it?

description.text:
Print 2 pieces, cut 4 small diameter (mine were 2.9mm) metal rods (trimmed steel nails, for instance) around 2cm long. Put one in each side making sure they have one end exactly in the inner hole limit. Put a piece of filament in the other extreme and glue it. Trimm the excess filament after glue is dry. Repeat for the other side. Metal rods should slide easily and freely.  
Remember to do 2 pieces like so and then insert one on the other and after shaking it a little bit try to separate both :-)   
UPDATE: see the PDF for a graphical illustration of the assembly instructions. Happy puzzling :-)  
Good luck!  
PS: if it is not clear let me know and I'll try to illustrate the assembly a bit more.
